content.raw:
Yes, and this is appealing since we do so much back and forth in the branches while the pull request is being discussed that most of the history is pretty useless - but it visibly happens in the branch so it looks somewhat sensible still in the commit tree.

But since bitbucket presents squashing as a seeming alternative to a merge commit, it makes me wonder if the 'squashed' commit just appears in the default branch.

Maybe this would be a good way to start going about things, though it would leave the poor author of the pull request with an extra branch to prune, which is a bit unfriendly to newcomers still familiarising themselves with the tools.

Maybe time for some experiments.
